dublin_core.dcvalue: This study examined the relationships between the use of personal digital assistants and self efficacy and the preparation for medication administration among second year Bachelor of Science in Nursing students in a medical surgical clinical environment By using a controlled experimental method the study attempted to support claims about the educational benefits of personal digital assistants which have generally been reported in more descriptive and anecdotal formats The sample consisted of 36 students of which two groups had personal digital assistants and two groups served as a control The control groups were provided with paper resources equivalent to the software provided by the personal digital assistants Findings showed a significant increase in self efficacy in the groups with personal digital assistants
Made available in DSpace on 2020-02-06T15:54:32Z (GMT). No. of bitstreams: 0 Previous issue date: 2006-05-18
The use of personal digital assistants at the point of care in an undergraduate nursing program.
